banality.example: Herbert regarded the minister's remark as a mere banality until Sharon pointed out profound implications to the seemingly obvious words.

polemic.explanation: a strong verbal or written attack on someone or something.
polemic.example: The professor launched into a polemic, claiming that Freudian theory was a pack of lies that absolutely destroyed European literary theory.

sullen.example: Herbert took board games too seriously, often appearing sullen after losing.

misconstrue.example: The politician never trusted journalists because he thought that they would misconstrue his words and misrepresent his positions.

mundane.example: Nancy found doing dishes a thoroughly mundane task, although Peter found a kind of Zen pleasure in the chore.

duress.example: The witness said he signed the contract under duress and argued that the court should cancel the agreement.

erudite.example: Before the Internet, the library was typically where you would find erudite readers.

antipathy.explanation: an intense feeling of dislike or aversion
antipathy.example: Maria had an antipathy for tour groups, often bolting to the other side of the museum as soon as she saw a chaperone leading a group of wide-eyed tourists.

capricious.explanation: determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
capricious.example: Nearly every month our capricious CEO had a new plan to turn the company around, and none of them worked because we never gave them the time they needed to succeed.

reproach.example: At first, Sarah was going to yell at the boy, but she didn't want to reproach him for telling the truth about the situation.

anomaly.explanation: something that is not normal, standard, or expected
anomaly.example: After finding an anomaly in the data, she knew that she would have to conduct her experiment again.

specious.example: Almost every image on TV is specious and not to be trusted.

imprudent.example: Hitler, like Napoleon, made the imprudent move of invading Russia in winter, suffering even more casualties than Napoleon had.

dispassionate.explanation: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
dispassionate.example: A good scientist should be dispassionate, focusing purely on what the evidence says, without personal attachment.

arduous.explanation: demanding considerable mental effort and skill; testing powers of endurance
arduous.example: In order to deal with the arduous cross-country journey, truck drivers often survive on a string of caffeinated drinks, staying awake for up to 30 hours at a time.

magoosh-score-estimator.explanation: After taking a practice exam, determine your score on the GRE 340-point scale.  Learn more at http
magoosh-score-estimator.example: Mike scored a 335 on a practice exam using the Magoosh score estimator.

opulence.explanation: wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living
opulence.example: Russian oligarchs are famous for their opulence, living in fancy homes and dining on expensive caviar.

posit.example: Initially, Einstein posited a repulsive force to balance Gravity, but then rejected that idea as a blunder.

placate.explanation: cause to be more favorably inclined; gain the good will of
placate.example: I was able to placate the angry mob of students by promising to bring cookies on Monday.

furtive.explanation: marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed
furtive.example: While at work, George and his boss Regina felt the need to be as furtive as possible about their romantic relationship.

elicit.example: Just smiling--even if you are depressed--can elicit feelings of pleasure and happiness.

mendacity.example: I can forgive her for her mendacity but only because she is a child and is seeing what she can get away with.

truncate.example: The soccer game was truncated when the monsoon rain began to fall.

maladroit.example: As a child she was quite maladroit, but as an adult, she has become an adept dancer.

nonplussed.explanation: unsure how to act or respond
nonplussed.example: Shirley was totally nonplussed when the angry motorist cut her off and then stuck his finger out the window.

transient.example: The unpredictable and transient nature of deja vu makes it a very difficult phenomenon to study properly.

rebuke.example: The police chief rebuked the two officers whose irresponsible decisions almost led to the deaths of seven innocent by-standers.

nuance.explanation: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
nuance.example: Because of the nuances involved in this case, I hired an outside consultant to advise us and help.

indecorous.explanation: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society
indecorous.example: Eating with elbows on the table is considered indecorous in refined circles.

economical.example: Journalists favor an economical style of writing, in which no unnecessary words are used and every sentence is as short as possible.

esoteric.explanation: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle
esoteric.example: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pastime.

efficacious.example: Since Maggie's cough syrup, which had expired five years back, was no longer efficacious, she coughed through the night.

impartial.explanation: free from undue bias or preconceived opinions
impartial.example: The judge was not impartial since he had been bribed by the witness's family.

askance.explanation: with a look of suspicion or disapproval
askance.example: The old couple looked askance on the teenagers seated next to them, whispering to each other, "They've got rings through their noses and purple hair!"

disseminate.example: Before the effects of anesthesia were disseminated, patients had to experience the full pain of a surgery.

dilatory.example: Lawyers use dilatory tactics so that it takes years before the case is actually decided.

contrition.explanation: the feeling of remorse or guilt that comes from doing something bad
contrition.example: Those who show contrition during their prison terms--especially when under review by a parole board--often get shortened sentences.

stringent.explanation: demanding strict attention to rules and procedures
stringent.example: Most of the students disliked the teacher because of his stringent homework policy, but many students would later thank him for demanding so much from them.

appease.explanation: pacify by acceding to the demands of
appease.example: Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister during WWII, tried to appease Hitler and in doing so sent a clear message: you can walk all over us.

ignominious.explanation: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
ignominious.example: Since the politician preached ethics and morality, his texting of revealing photographs was ignominious, bringing shame on both himself and his party.

harried.explanation: troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances
harried.example: With a team of new hires to train, Martha was constantly harried with little questions and could not focus on her projects.

timorous.explanation: timid by nature or revealing fear and nervousness
timorous.example: Since this was her first time debating on stage and before an audience, Di's voice was timorous and quiet for the first 10 minutes.

fastidious.example: Whitney is fastidious about her shoes, arranging them on a shelf in a specific order, each pair evenly spaced.

deleterious.example: The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was deleterious to the fishing industry in the southern states.

jovial.explanation: full of or showing high-spirited merriment
jovial.example: The presidential candidate and her supporters were jovial once it was clear that she had won.

craven.example: Though the man could have at least alerted the police, he crouched cravenly in the corner as the old woman was mugged.

bolster.example: The case for the suspect's innocence was bolstered considerably by the fact that neither fingerprints nor DNA were found at the scene.

flux.explanation: a state of uncertainty about what should be done (usually following some important event)
flux.example: Ever since Elvira resigned as the head of marketing, everything about our sales strategy has been in a state of flux.

pejorative.explanation: expressing disapproval (usu. refers to a term)
pejorative.example: Most psychologists object to the pejorative term "shrink", believing that they expand the human mind, not limit it.

maverick.explanation: someone who exhibits great independence in thought and action
maverick.example: Officer Kelly was a maverick, rarely following police protocols or adopting the conventions for speech common among his fellow officers.

edifying.explanation: enlightening or uplifting so as to encourage intellectual or moral improvement
edifying.example: I recently read an article in the Times about whether good literature is edifying or not; specifically, does reading more make a person more moral.
